article_title: HUD chief Castro announces rules to end housing segregation
article_text:
HUD chief Castro announces rules to end housing segregation

WASHINGTON — Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro on Wednesday released long-awaited new rules to promote integrated neighborhoods, a goal that has lagged in many cities, despite a 1960s ban on racial discrimination.

article_metadata.description: WASHINGTON — Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro on Wednesday released long-awaited new rules to promote integrated neighborhoods, a goal that has lagged in many cities, despite a 1960s ban on racial discrimination.  The new rules, a top priority of civil rights advocates, mark another use of executive power by President Barack Obama to tackle what his administration regards as inequities in society.  The agency cited a Government Accountability Office report in 2010 that found a lack of clarity, standards and transparency in the obligations of communities to live up to requirements under the Fair Housing Act.  Melody Woosley, director of the San Antonio Human Service Department, praised the new rules, saying they “improve past regulations and provide the opportunity for full community input on the issue of housing for the low-income and disabled populations.”
article_metadata.author.name: By Bill Lambrecht, Washington Bureau
